Accommodation:  Camping at
Seronera Public Campsite or similar (dome tent)
Meals:
Breakfast:   At
the Camp
Lunch:  Picnic
lunch collected from the camp
Dinner:  At
the Camp


Day 5:  Serengeti National Park, Tanzania  


Today you
will enjoy a full day game viewing exploring the endless plains of this
magnificent place. The Seronera River is the life blood of the Serengeti in the
dry season and this area is renowned for great game viewing all year round and
is especially popular for sightings of the elusive leopard.
Accommodation:  Camping at Seronera Public Campsite or similar (dome tent)
Meals:
Breakfast:   At
the Camp
Lunch:  Picnic
lunch collected from the camp
Dinner:  At
the Camp


Day 6:Ngorongoro
National Park, Tanzania  

We take an
early breakfast at the camp and then head to the spectacular Ngorongoro Crater.
On arrival we go through the registration process and descend to the floor of
the world’s largest unbroken caldera for the most wonderful day of game
viewing. We will have lunch at the designated picnic site at the side of the
hippo pool and continue with a game drive as we drive up the crater rim for
overnight.
Accommodation:  Camping at Panorama Campsite or similar (dome tent)
Meals:
Breakfast:   At
the Camp
Lunch:  Picnic
lunch collected from the camp
Dinner:  At
the Camp


Day 7:  Ngorongoro – Arusha, Tanzania  

After
breakfast we explore the colourful town of Mto-wa-Mbu for some last minute
pictures and curio shopping. Afterwards we head to Arusha where the tour will
end at our offices. We hope to welcome you again on one of our African
adventures!
Meals:
Breakfast:  At the Camp   
END
OF TOUR


Pre – departure
information
Departure
The Tanzania
Wildlife Safaris departs from the African Tulip Hotel in Arusha. When arriving
in Arusha on day one, you will be picked up from the airport and transferred to
your hotel. Should you arrive prior to day one, pre-tour accommodation can be
arranged and you will be picked up from your hotel on the morning of day. 
In the
evening of first day of your safari, there will be a pre-departure meeting
presented by your guide at your accommodation. It is imperative that all
clients attend this meeting so as not to miss out on any critical information.
Whilst it is
our every intention to adhere to the above mentioned itinerary, there may on
occasion be a necessity to make alterations in order to make the tour more
enjoyable or practical.  Therefore please
treat the itinerary as a guide only.
Transport
Steppe Dogs
Adventures uses fully equipped customized 8-seater 4x4 safari vehicles, Toyota
Land Cruisers or other appropriate vehicles with comfortable seating, large
windows for game viewing and a music system. The vehicles are fully
air-conditioned and equipped with pop-up roofs to facilitate the best game
viewing. All luggages, besides hand luggage and photo equipment, are carried on
the vehicle roof rack to ensure maximum comfort in the vehicle.
Traveling Times & Distances
All
travelling times are affected by road conditions, border crossings, detours and
weather conditions, therefore on certain days travelling times may be longer
than anticipated especially where there is a lot of distance to be covered. 
Please keep in mind that the time it takes to travel 100 km in your home
country is not equivalent to the time it takes to travel 100 km on African
roads, therefore we encourage you to sit
back and enjoy the spectacular scenery Africa has to offer.  Where
possible additional stops will be made to ensure you’re travelling comfort at
all times.

Accommodation
We make use of designated
campsites, either within a National Park or on the banks of a river, or other
places of interest. All campsites have shared ablution facilities with showers,
flushing toilets and running water (unless otherwise specified in the detailed
itinerary). Steppe Dogs Adventures tries to avoid crowded campsites and brings
you to secluded spots, often supported by the local community. We make use of
3-person dome tents with the following measurements: 2.5 m x 2. 5 m x 1.8 m and
accommodate two clients per tent. All tents are fitted with mosquito-screed
windows and doors. In addition, we provide 5 cm thick sleeping mattresses.
Sleeping bags can be hired at an additional fee of US$ 30 per sleeping bag for
the entire tour.

For the lodge safari, we make use of typical, mid-range African
standard lodge accommodation. Accommodation is situated either in national parks,
on the banks of a river, or in other places of interest. The accommodation will
be a mix of lodges, chalets and tented camps, all with en-suite facilities.
Some properties are equipped with swimming pools and/or bar areas.

Spending money
Clients are
advised to bring enough money to cover the purchase of curios, tips for the
guide and additional entertainment. US Dollars and Tanzanian Shilling are the
most practical and convenient currencies.
Meals
All meals
will be prepared by your guide, either around a campfire in the evening or at a
picnic site for lunch. Please advise us of any special dietary requirements in
advance.
First Aid Kit
Our guides
are trained in basic first aid and the vehicle is equipped with a medical aid
kit. Preventative Malaria medication should be taken before the trip and
throughout its duration and it is advisable to consult a doctor prior to
departure. Yellow Fever vaccinations are compulsory – please contact your
Travel Clinic before departure.

Luggage: 
Maximum baggage allowance: 12 kg. Steppe Dogs Adventures Tanzania
stipulates this luggage allowance, as an overloaded vehicle is a danger to both
the clients and the guide. This does not include photographic equipment and a
small daypack. Please bring soft-sided luggage (e.g. a backpack or soft barrel
bag), not a suitcase. Don't bring too much clothing, as there are washing
opportunities along the way. Please adhere to the allowance specified as space
for luggage is limited.
Insurance:
It is compulsory for all travellers to have insurance covering
their personal requirements, medical expenses and personal possessions. This is
to be arranged before leaving your home country. Steppe Dogs Adventures has
comprehensive public liability insurance.


Packing:
Shorts  Track
suit  walking
shoes
Light trousers/jeans  Swimming
costume  Sandals 
T-shirts  Sun
hat  Windbreaker
Warm clothes (May – August)  Long-sleeved
shirts   Camera
Torch  Mosquito
protection  
UV protection   Spare batteries

Visas:
The onus is
on the client to organize all visas required to visit Tanzania prior to departure.


Detailed Information on Areas Visited
Tanzania
A land of
plains, lakes and mountains, with a narrow, low-lying coastal belt, Tanzania is
East Africa's largest country and also one of its most diverse.  Tanzania is home for more than 100 different
ethnic groups, mostly of Bantu origin, each with its own language and customs. 
Tanzania has
one of the largest and wildest animal populations in the world.  Wildebeest, monkey, antelope, lion, cheetah,
crocodile, gazelle, and flamingo - you name them. Blessed with some of the
world's largest game reserves, the country also has one of the highest
concentrations of elephant, buffalo, hippo, wild dog and chimpanzee.
Its
spectacular topography includes The Great Rift Valley, Mt Kilimanjaro and
famous parks such as the Serengeti and the wonderful Ngorongoro Crater.
Offshore are
idyllic islands with beautiful palm-fringed beaches and turquoise seas that
surround pristine coral reefs.  The
archaeological treasures of Tanzania include hominid fossils, which are more
than 300 million years old.  Tanzanian
music and dance dominates much of East Africa. 
Strong in rhythm and renowned for hard-hitting lyrics, the country's
Swahili-based sounds are kept very much alive by a thriving dance-band
scene.  Nyama choma (barbecued
meat) has taken over in a big way, especially in restaurants with attached
bars.  But on the coast, on Zanzibar and
Pemba islands, there's a decent range of traditional Swahili dishes based on
seafood.



Recorded
history begins around 1800, when the Masai warrior tribes were migrating from
Kenya to Tanzania.  It wasn't until the
middle of the 18th century that Arab traders and slaves dared venture into
Masai territory in the country's wild interior. 
European explorers began arriving in earnest in the mid-19th century,
the most famous being Stanley and Livingstone. 
The famous phrase ‘Dr Livingstone, I presume’, stems from the duo's
meeting at Ujiji on Lake Tanganyika. Tanganyika won independence in 1961 with
Julius Nyerere as the country's first president. Nyerere, whose secret
ingredient was radical socialism, gained widespread respect and is seen as one
of the most influential leaders Africa has ever had.  Zanzibar was stuck for another two years,
after which the mainland forged a union comprising Zanzibar and the nearby
island of Pemba. Thus Tanzania was born.
There is a
wide range of optional activities to make your experience in Tanzania
absolutely unforgettable.  Some great
views can be experienced while floating in a hot-air balloon over the
Serengeti.  While swimming with dolphins
is all the rage on the island of Zanzibar. 
Snorkelling and scuba diving is equally popular due to the world-class
coral reefs off nearby Pemba and Mafia
Tarangire National Park
The Tarangire
National Park covers 2,600km² and habits the highest concentration of wildlife
outside the Serengeti ecosystem. Here, you can watch huge herds of wildebeest,
eland, zebra, buffalo, impala, gazelle and elephant moving through the
undulating countryside and taking a rest under a vast number of baobab trees,
or drinking at the lagoons and the rivers. Remember not to just look on the
ground though, but have a look at the branches of the trees for lion, leopard
and pythons or the amazing 550 bird species also found in this area.


Lake Manyara National Park:
Lake Manyara
National Park sits at the base of the Great Rift Valley escarpment and is one
of the most scenic parks in Tanzania. There are stunning views of the park from
every direction. From the east, the Rift Valley escarpment emerges on the
horizon with the lake forming a glistening background. On the southern side of
the park, you will find the hot springs of Maji Moto, which are about 60ºC. At
the top of the escarpment from the west, the park stretches across a ribbon of
green with the lake shining in the sun. Like most Rift Valley lakes, the water
is alkaline. This attracts vast flocks of flamingos, which form pink foam
against a silver background of water. Altogether, this area offers beautiful
views as you take in the massive lake with its silver shimmer and surrounding
vegetation.
The major
landmark is the spectacular rift wall, where the plains give way to cultivated
uplands of Mbululand. Measuring only 330km2 (of which the lake
occupies 230km2) and located only 130km from Arusha, this park often
gets day visitors, who come to enjoy the endless views and variety of mammals,
reptiles and birds, as well as the varied vegetation, flora and fauna.
Animals found
in the area include zebra, elephant, hippo, monkey, wildebeest (gnu),
waterbuck, warthog, gazelle, impala, buffalo, warthog, hyena, baboon and
giraffe. Manyara is also known for its tree-climbing lions. These majestic
animals find shelter from the heat and biting flies in the branches of trees
and can easily kill buffalo, which is far greater in weight and size. There are
also over 350 species of bird life, with a variety of local species inhabiting
the forest and bush, including pelicans that waddle around next to short
grasses on the shore of the lake.
Serengeti National Park:
Serengeti,
which sprawls across 14.763 km2 (5.757 miles2), is
Tanzania’s largest and most famous national park. The chief herbivore of
Serengeti is the wildebeest (gnu) of which there are up to two million. The
amazing annual migration of wildebeest herds is one of the biggest attractions
of the Serengeti. It begins at the Serengeti National Park near the Kenyan
border, when huge herds of these animals, head for greener pastures in
Kenya.  Starting in April each year, they
migrate across the Serengeti's southern plains accompanied by zebra, antelope,
gazelle, lion and tourists! The park is also famous for its lions, which can be
tracked due to the fact that many have collars fitted with transmitters, as
well as cheetah and large herds of giraffe.


Ngorongoro Conservation Area:
Being one of
the largest calderas in the world, 20 km (12.4 miles)-wide, 600 m (1.968ft)
tall, with a variety of animals and vegetation, Ngorongoro Crater is one of
Tanzania’s most visited areas. The vegetation includes grasslands, swamps,
forests, salt-pans, as well as a freshwater lake and has been compared to
Noah's Ark or the Garden of Eden.  



You will have
no trouble finding lion, elephant, rhino, buffalo and many of the plains
herbivores such as wildebeest (gnu), Thomson's gazelle, zebra and reedbuck, as
well as thousands of flamingos wading in the shallows of Lake Magadi, the soda
lake on the floor of the crater. Within the steep walls of the crater you will
find considerable movement of animals and you may well come across local Masai
tribesmen (who have grazing rights here), tending their cattle.

Maasai at Ngorongoro 

The Maasai of Tanzania are an indigenous pastoral society with a
rich and vibrant oral history.
Maasai
Their traditional knowledge, often narrated in the form of
folktales, songs, stories, poetry, and chants, contains a wide-range of
knowledge about traditional medicine, grazing practices, landscape ecology, the
behavior of animals, livestock management, and the gathering of wild plant
foods. 
Maasai pastoralists represent the highest degree of pastoral
specialization in the Eastern-Sudanic region of East Africa. Maasai peoples,
however, also combine livestock herding with other economic activities such as
cultivation, trade, and gathering. Because of their dependence on natural
resources to sustain livestock and human populations (such as natural watering
sites, grazing areas, agricultural land, and drought reserves), many Maasai
groups that historically depended on community grazing structures and local,
opportunistic agriculture suffered economically when they were forced onto
smaller parcels of settled land. This conflict arose as colonial, and later
local governments began instituting land reform programs that transformed
Maasai lands in Kenya and Tanzania into group ranches, privatized settler
farms, national parks, game reserves, and hunting areas. In 1911, Maasai lands
in Kenya were reduced by 60 percent when the British evicted them to make room
for settler ranches, subsequently confining them to present-day Kajiado and
Narok districts. Maasai lands were further enclosed to allow for the creation
of game parks, including Amboseli, Nairobi, and Masai Mara in Kenya and the
Serengeti/Ngorongoro Conservation Area in Tanzania. Ndagala states that were
the colonial and post-colonial eviction of the pastoralists from some of their
best grazing lands were rationalized to protect the wildlife. The transfer of
these lands has served to enclose many pastoral and semi agricultural groups
onto parcels of lands that are unsuitable for either semi-nomadic pastoralism
or agriculture at a sustainable level. 

Maasai woman showing hospitality to her visitor by covering her by Maasai shuka. Support us and will send you one shuka.
After independence, Tanzania implemented a socialist policy of
villagazation, a program to promote sustainability, development, and
nationalism. In Maasai areas, this meant that people were physically resettled
into bomas, a circular cluster of homes. The bomas, which were formerly kin
settlements, were now neighborly groupings of individual families. In 1976, the
government officially resettled the Maasai in Monduli and gave them a maximum
of three acres of land each to farm (Ndagala: 1982). Whereas the Maasai
previously thought of grazing fields as a community resource (Ndagala 1992),
each family now owned its own plot of land. In the shift to a more sedentary
lifestyle, the Maasai in Monduli Juu became a pastoralist community where they
cultivated both maize and beans and kept extensive herds of livestock. In this
sense, they were likened to ilmeek, outsiders or non-Maasai, whom they had
formerly despised because they did not value grass, a significant source of
life for pastoralists (Galaty 1981:4; Hodgson 1999). In the words of one woman
in Eluai Village, “There used to be so many cows that the grass would not reach
the door of the house; now there is [unused] grass everywhere.” 





Dance with Maasai tribe, see their unique house building and learn their ways of life from their elders!

This subsequently placed the Maasai at odds with their
environment, both culturally and economically. Without livestock, a Maasai male
is presented with many difficulties. These difficulties include the inability
to obtain sufficient food, lack of money to buy grains, inability to put up a
good house, and if unmarried, he may not be able to attract a wife. Thus, the
privatization of land ultimately increased the relative poverty of those living
in Eluai and led to a more individualistic view of maintaining the environment.
Instead of protecting the communal character of grazing lands, those who
cultivated farms destroyed grass; an act seen as an aggression against Engai.
As a result, trees, which were formerly regarded as objects of refuge, ritual,
and healing, became capital to be owned and used or sold in the same way
livestock once was, by whoever held the land they grew on. 


1. Engai is the
Maasai name for God. In the Maasai language, en- is the feminine prefix and God
is associated with femininity; as a mother creator and protector of all natural
things.





After long safari on our national parks or from 
Kilimanjaro climbing extend your trip to Zanzibar where you will spend 
your 3 or 4 days on beaches and learn some Zanzibar cultures.


Website & Our social networks:Website:    http://www.steppedogsadventures.com/Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/steppedogsadventuresTwitter:  https://twitter.com/SteppeDogsThank you so much...every bit is very much appreciated!!

story:
My Story:

I have lived and traveled all over the world: Morocco, Spain, Greece, Turkey, India and from coast to coast in the U.S.A. I settled in Va Beach, Va after being a navy brat for many years. This is now the place I call home. Hampton Roads is very near and dear to my heart. My entire family is here and all 3 of my beautiful children. Traveling has made me learn so much about different cuisines, flavors, and cultures of the world. I am 50 years old taking on a new business venture. With that comes all of the stresses of being uncertain if you will succeed, but I am willing to risk it all to pursue my dream.

 I helped start multiple restaurants in opening from the ground up and build their reputation. I did this by making sure I was there every single day to greet my customers and create a face to face relationship. I have always been a very hard worker and driven individual. Cooking has always been a true passion of mine since I was a little girl. I love creating new dishes and flavors with fresh ingredients for all of my loved ones. Feeding and serving people is truly what I love to do.

The turning point in my own life was when I faced an array of health challenges: colitis, digestive problems, polyps, and early signs of cancer.  That was enough to scare me, and drive me to change! I did some reevaluating, and started to pay attention to my body, focus on not only my body's health but also mental health and reduced stresses in my life.  I then began to see the relationship between mind, body, and spirit.

I want to help people live and heal through healthy food that tastes fantastic too!

Khadija's Moroccan Cuzina is a start-up local business that is bringing together a vegetarian mix of world foods and flavors: Old World Mediterranean, North African, Moroccan, and Indian. I do this with a commitment to clean whole foods that are organic, colorful, vibrant and alive.

I need your help to make this possible! I have funded this business all on my own up to this point and come March will be at a stand still for funds. Please help me provide delicious Vegan/ Vegetarian food to this Hampton Roads community that I love.

The Mission of Khadija's Moroccan Cuzina is to:

·  Deliver the finest Hand Crafted Food possible.

·  Provide vegetarian, vegan, and gluten free products that taste GREAT!

·  Helping people use these foods in multiple creative ways.


What We Need & What You'll Get

Our Goal

To raise $150,000 by March to put Khadija's Moroccan Cuzina in a Brick & Mortar Store Front.

Perks

See perks on sidebar.

The Impact

·  Khadija's Moroccan Cuzina was launched in August of 2015.

·  Products have been marketed via social media & local outlets.

·  Cooking & food prep currently happens in an apartment with a certified kitchen.

. Everything has been funded from personal resources that will run out in March.

·  Success requires the business to relocate to its own storefront.

·  A food truck is needed for catering, events, and promotions.

·  This unique business is ready to go to the next level.

·  We need your help with funding.

Risks & Challenges

§  We are operating out of an apartment. - the frig is in the living room!

§  We have a certified kitchen - but can only do prepackaged foods.

§  This limits our ability to meet the growing demand for products.

§  We currently can't do mass production.

§  With our current setup we can't get food insurance.

§  We are already low on funds for packaging and labeling.

§  We want to add a juice bar but are unable to without a store.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, you might know someone who is in a position to help.  You can also go to our Facebook page or website and order some of our food.  Love and Gratitude!

story:
Short Summary

Our directory makes listed websites rank higher in search engine results, not our own site like our competitors. We simply want to improve the online experience for consumers in Norway. Oh, and were cheaper too (our competitors are overpriced).

But we don’t have a sales organization.

Bedriftsbasen.no was established in 2005 and is one of the most visited Norwegian business search directories and a member of The World Wide Web Chamber of Commerce.

Bedriftsbasen.no has been featured by FOX, CBS, ABC, NBC, Bloomberg, Digital Magazine, Townhall and The Telegraph.

We Need 25,000 USD

The funds raised will cover:

  • Establishing a sales organization.
  • Accounting.
  • Office rent the first few months.
  • Computers/phones.

The perks

This is really important to us so we are bending over backwards to make you happy. We have some serious perks:

  • Premium SEO links.
  • High value organic blogposts and social sharing.
If we don’t reach our goal we will improve our site, invest in a affiliate marketing campaign and make an app.

The Impact

Your contribution will change the way people use and perceive their online experience in Norway. Also, you will enable unemployed people work doing something valuable and meaningful.

Risks & Challenges

There are some risks and obstacles on the way to a successful launch. However Bedriftsbasen.no is managed by Gunnar Andreassen, an online marketing expert and published author. And he is a Google AdWords and Google Analytics certified partner.

He's is a member of Web Design Professionals, Web Design and Developers Association, Interaction Design Association and International Webmaster Association.

Gunnar Andreassen has been featured by CNN, Miami Herald, Forbes, The Sun, Examiner, WND, Siliconvalley.com and Silicon Investor. Andreassen has also experience in telemarketing with documented record sales.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Contact us if you have any questions. Thanks :)

story:
The Challenge and Our Solution 

You want to do good, like giving a cake to a child. But, in the humanitarian aid industry, everyone is taking a slice of the child's cake... By the time it reaches him, only a few crumbs are left. 

Here, when you buy a "cake" through our campaign, a child in need gets the entire thing!

It’s as simple as it should be.

The "cake" you are buying from our campaign is actually life saving food. And, thanks to your generosity, the child will get to celebrate his or her next birthday!

Who We Are

The 3 Million Club is a sustainable non-profit organization that is revolutionizing the way people support, deliver and receive life-saving humanitarian aid. 

You know how easy it is to order something from Amazon.com or a taxi from phone with Uber? Well, we’re making it just as easy to save a life—in just a few clicks of your mouse or swipes of your screen. How?

We’ve built a platform that works just like an e-commerce shop, only instead of directly delivering products to your doorstep, it directly delivers life-saving products to those in need on your behalf. And the entirety of your purchase goes to helping those in need. For example, when you purchase therapeutic food for malnourished children through our platform, no one takes a cut of your purchase—not the manufacturer of the food, not the local charity administering it, and not us. 

And just like any online order, you can track the journey of your life-saving purchase. Even better, you can stay updated on the progress of those whose lives you saved.


Help us change the way humanitarian aid is done. Through our campaign, you’ll support non-profit efficiency, transparency, and most important of all, the lives of those in need.


What We Need & What You Get

We saved 1,700 children in Haiti in just six months' time with only $102,000. If you do the math, that means it cost only $60 to save each child. 

This holiday season, we are partnering with a local charity called Real Hope for Haiti to save the lives of 300 more children who they are treating for malnourishment.    

Here's the math broken down:

  • $60 = A 3-month supply of therapeutic food needed to save one child
  • 300 = The number of children in Haiti we need to save
  • $60 X 300 = $18,000, which you'll help us raise!

The Impact

We are privileged to have already seen a life-changing impact on the children we've saved in Haiti. Thanks to our supporters who purchased therapeutic food, a whopping 1,700 near-death children were nourished back to health. 

Facts and figures:

  • Nearly 3 million children under age five suffer from life-threatening malnutrition. (That's why we're call the "3 Million Club").
  • It takes only 3-months of food treatment for the children to recover
  • The 3-month course of food treatment only costs $60
  • When you purchase food from our campaign, it is produced locally, which stimulated Haiti's economy in addition to saving the children.
  • Your purchase also helps empower our local charity partner, Real Hope for Haiti, which knows the community better than any large, international NGO

Challenges with Traditional aid 

  • It’s Unsustainable - Reliant on foreign delivery and funding. 
  • It’s Insufficient - In 2013 Foreign aid failed to reach 1/3 of people in need.
  • It’s Wasteful - Intermediates take cuts until little is left for those in need.
  • It’s Unaccountable - In 2012,  data on 30% of humanitarian funding was missing/unaccounted for.

3MC's Challenges 

We face our own unique challenges, but we are transparent about them. Our biggest challenge is to continue to improve and scale our platform, which allows you to purchase life-saving products in a few simple clicks of your mouse or swipes of your screen. However, we have entrepreneurial agnels who are helping us meet this challenge financially. 

Meanwhile, 100% of the spending on our platform goes to the purchase of life-saving products. That's why you can have the peace of mind knowing that when you purchase therapeutic food through our campaign, each dollar is going to feed malnourished children.

Other Ways You Can Help

We welcome any contribution you can make. Even a purchase of $5 worth of therapeutic food will help save a precious life. But there are other things you can do as well:

  • Spread the Word- If you believe in our mission and want to help save lives, please share our campaign amongst your network of friends, family, and colleagues!
  • Follow Us- We also want to build our base of supporters and share exciting updates with you. Please follow us on Facebook and Twitter to stay informed on our latest live-saving projects!

Thank you for helping us save lives this holiday season!

Happy Holidays!

story:
Short Summary

Thank you for stopping to read our story and help with our cause.

My name is Linda Otterbridge and I founded Hook a Sista Up in June 2013.  Hook a Sista up is a platform for women entrepreneurs to help them with support, mentorship, resources, hook-up's and sponsorships on their journey in getting their businesses launched and or sustaining an already existing business.

 HASU is having a growth spurt and need your help.  We need your help with expanding  and upgrading our website and technology  to better serve our HASU and future members.

 This will help women get their ideas and dreams off the ground  through connecting with mentors, other women entrepreneurs, learning about resources and gaining hook-ups can help them create a livelihood for their families and add to the economic growth of their communities. 

Our technology campaign is to help us continue the work we are doing on a larger scale and for more women entrepreneurs.  We are heading into our fourth year and need your help with finances for our website and technology upgrades

Your contribution today will help us expand our efforts to help more women with resources, marketing, promotion and workshops to better equip them to be sustainable in their businesses.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

To help us continue to support and serve women entrepreneurs we need capacity funding support.  As mentioned earlier HASU has had a growth spurt and need to grow to fit the demand.  Your financial support will help us in  these areas

  • Provide  a new website and technology upgrades to manage all our new member needs
  • Purchase donor  and volunteers management software
  • Fund a web series to get our message and programs to other cities to impact other women entrepreneurs
HASU will add you to our website as supporters  and donors that helped in our growth campaign and will also add you to all printed material as a donor to our cause throughout the year.
 

The Impact

This technology campaign and the money you give will help us grow our movement by engaging our members through technology, being more efficient and have more accessibility to the community and other platforms.

Our movement for women entrepreneurs have existed since 2013 due to our resilience, sweat equity and  accountability to members and the community and the community and members dedication and commitment to HASU.     We are willing and ready to help even more women entrepreneurs with your help today.

 

Risks & Challenges

One of our main challenges are our limited funds to do the work of helping our women entrepreneurs launch and sustain their businesses by providing various resources and connections.

Another challenge would be our limited website capabilities and not having upgraded technology and programs. 

 

 A new and updated website would allow us to add a member user and login option and a search button to locate HASU members and their business profiles in hopes of doing business with them in the future.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are a multitude of ways you can help our cause if you cannot give today.

  • Make some noise about our cause and share in your networks to get others to give to our  Growth Capacity Campaign. 
  • Be open to mentoring and or sponsoring one of our women entrepreneurs.
  • Donate donor management tools to help  us with tracking our members and sponsors
  • Become a small business and or corporate member of HASU
  • Place you business ad, job openings and or volunteer opportunities on our website
  • Volunteer as a content and website design manager.  Or donate your time and experience to help further our HASU goals.

story:
The Rise of Bootie Camp Yoga®

Hi, it's Michelle Trabelsi, as you know, I am the creator of Bootie Camp Yoga®, a power yoga based fitness program that sculpts the derriere!  I created Bootie Camp Yoga® 4 years ago because my booty needed a little more than my "Power, Flow & Balance" Yoga practice had to offer.  I wanted to create a challenging work out that was safe for those with injuries, like myself, that was completely kick-butt, and that also offered deep stretching!

This FUN hobby of mine has blossomed into a popular & nationally accredited fitness program that Las Vegas people call "Vegas's BEST Kept Secret".  Bootie Camp Yoga® is in over 15 gyms in Southern California, 4 in Las Vegas, with certified instructors in 5 other states, two of which were certified virtually!  To date, I have  certified over 50 Bootie Camp Yoga® instructors & trainees, 30 of which are actively teaching in both small & well known fitness centers such as, Gold's Gym & YMCA!

Bootie Camp Yoga® has grown organically in a small area, and in a relatively short amount of time.  I am at a place where instructors in other areas on the planet are not only SUPER interested in teaching this format, but also becoming master instructors in their area. THIS is EXCITING!  The fact that I can certify instructor's virtually is even more exciting!

Bootie Camp Yoga® was voted BEST Recreational & Sporting Activity on Inland Empires 2014 HOT List, as well as we had our first feature story in a national publication: American Fitness Magazine, July/August 2015 issue.

As the creator, It's an AMAZING feeling to hear people in the community and instructors SO excited about Bootie Camp Yoga®!

I Need Your Help...

In order for Bootie Camp Yoga® to rise to it's maximum potential... & the possibilities are endless, I need your help!

A Breakdown...

-National Fitness Expos: Being a featured Presenter at 3 of the largest Fitness Expos in the country allows me to teach in front of hundreds of instructors that travel from different areas of the country & world, looking for something  unique to bring back to their gyms back home. Strategically placing my booth in a prime location & having on-stage presence is extremely important, and it's imperative to secure these slots ASAP to ensure the most exposure possible!


-Studio:  Wood floors to practice on. I need 26 boxes of $30 (per box) wood flooring laminate.


-Video Equipment: this is necessary to film virtual certifications & 60 min classes for the subscription site & phone app.

-Professional Videos & Promotional Trailers: I need to film two professionally edited videos for marketing on the BCY® website & most importantly to continuously loop during the Fitness Expos, on my booth display.

What YOU Get 4 Helping...

Please check out the PeRkS on the right side of this page...

NOT into BCY® or Yoga & still want to HELP?

-Pre-Pay for a class pass or monthly membership  stay stay at that rate FOREVER! -You can donate cuz you LOVE Me & BELIEVE in My Mission!
-You can sponsor a struggling Yogi, by purchasing a class pass.
-You can purchase a gift for a loved one, or provide a scholarship for a RAD human
  being that wants to teach BCY®/Yoga. Thank you in advance for your support!


Other Ways YOU Can Help...

Give BCY a shout out" and share what we’re up to with your community. Word of mouth is endlessly powerful! The more chatter, the better. If you’re strapped for cash, no worries! Follow me on Social media to learn about community classes & events hosted by  Bootie Camp Yoga®. 

Follow & SHARE this Campaign!

Thanks for reading and supporting Bootie Camp Yoga®. We look forward to seeing you "get your sweat on" very soon! Sharing  my campaign on your favorite flavor of social media, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, etc. helps me out as well!

story:
Short Summary 

The Care Plan is a Care Management & Mapping company based in Chicago IL.  We passionately provide expert health & aging advice to meet your immediate and long-term needs.  Whether facing an immediate health crisis or seeking to have a comprehensive plan for successful aging from retirement to end of life; our Navigation Managers possess the experience and resources to achieve your goals.  

We recognize the health disparities experienced by LGBTQI individuals and communities.  LGBTQI individuals are significantly less likely to have health insurance, to seek medical treatment, and to receive quality care.  The Care Plan strives to create a welcoming and affirming experience for LGBTQI clients, and develop provider competency across health and aging systems.    

Our Mission is to manifest positive outcomes in the field of aging and health through client directed Care Management & Mapping.  By assisting our clients to articulate and design their future, we empower people to overcome the many systemic obstacles which limit and prevent successful healthcare experiences.


About Us

The Care Plan was established August 1 of 2015 by Jacqueline Boyd, a community organizer, LGBTQI youth and elder advocate, and experienced senior care professional.  She has held positions as a Case Manager, Director of Client Services and Director of Operations within the field of senior care.  

In her personal and professional life, Jacqueline repeatedly witnessed how the immediate nature of health crisis kept people on a spinning wheel of uncertainty.  Clients and their loved ones, unfamiliar with health and aging systems experienced high degrees of confusion and anxiety, not sure where to turn, if they were making the right choices, and lacking knowledge of vital resources.  Without an advocate people would get lost in the system with multiple hospitalizations and poor care.  

For LGBTQI individuals, the process is often exponentially more harmful and traumatic.  Whether due to outright discrimination, prejudice, or ignorance of the concerns facing LGBTQI individuals, health & aging providers often add pain to an already difficult process.  

The Care Plan is the culmination of years of experience coupled with the desire to meet a growing need for client directed solutions within health and aging systems.  As part of our commitment to improving health & aging outcomes for the marginalized individuals, when we open our doors November 1, services are sliding scale for trans* and gender spectrum clients.   


Your Impact

Up to this point, The Care Plan development has been self-funded by the founder.  The contributions from this campaign are seed money for operational costs to get the business up and running.  The sooner we achieve our goal of $10,000, the sooner we can meet the growing need for LGBTQI competent healthcare advocates.  

Specifically your dollars will go towards paying for the following

  • Website Development
  • Awareness Raising Print & Video Materials
  • Product Development
  • City, State & Federal Licensing Fees
  • Professional & Liability Insurance
  • Intern Stipend
  • Office Supplies

Services

MY CARE MAP- Our comprehensive road map, keeps you in the driver’s seat throughout the aging process.  We can significantly minimize the stress of making life-changing decisions under pressure by thoughtfully planning ahead.  Utilizing our care mapping service, informed choices about the challenges spanning from retirement to end of life care are made ahead of time.  My Care Map is a tailored guide to the future and contains health history, personal profile, retirement goals, support system, financial and legal resources, real estate holdings, advanced directives and most importantly, your vision for the future.  Give your loved ones the gift of clarity, and be confident that your decisions will be respected.


CARE CONSULTATION & MANAGEMENT - Our Navigation Managers provide expert assessment, advice and coordination across health and aging systems to achieve immediate goals for you or a loved one.  Support includes attending appointments, advocating with physicians and medical providers, planning sessions with family and support team, selecting facilities and providers, and referral to critical resources.  We help you understand your options and make informed decisions to improve quality of life.

Perks

We appreciate your support at every level!  The Care Plan services can be modified and exchanged if the perk packages don't exactly match your needs.  Most perks can be provided in person in the Chicagoland area, or via phone, or Skype.  Please contact us at info@the-care-plan.com to modify perks.  


Client & Community Support 

"When I was diagnosed with fast growing cervical cancer, Jackie's presence with me in doctor's appointments, during surgery, and in the recovery room gave me the confidence I needed to navigate successfully through a terrifying crisis, my way. I highly recommend Ms. Boyd's advocacy and health crisis management services for anyone facing a personal health emergency. She will ensure that you are steering your own destiny, and will support your choices in each step of your recovery journey."    

                                                                                  - Penny  

                                                                                     2012 Client

"Ms. Jacqueline Boyd is by far one of the hardest working activist for the LGBTQI community I have ever had the pleasure of working with. As a former fellow Leadership Team Member of a nonprofit that we both helped create from the ground up, I have gotten the opportunity to observe Jacqueline's ability to help uplift and empower those individuals in her community who have been neglected, ignored, or have had their voices silenced. It's not possible to find a more loving and dedicated person to help you navigate a sometimes difficult healthcare system and help you find the right solutions to your family's health care needs." 

                                                                                  -Dr. Katrina Sanford
                                                                                   Clinical Psychologist
                                                                                   Washington, DC 

"Jackie Boyd's number one asset: she puts people first. Jackie's passion for LGBTQI justice crosses boundaries of race, class, and geography as she brings together people who care deeply about the needs of LGBTQI persons.  As a pastor, I've experienced Jackie's commitment to help elders in the congregation navigate their care needs -- in particular, Jackie helped an older gay man (with no children, whose partner was deceased) to think about his future with his extended family and his church family; her compassion and knowledge combined to assist in moving him to the next step."

                                                                                   - Rev. Lois McCullen-Parr

We appreciate your support at every level!  The Care Plan services can be modified and exchanged if the perk packages don't exactly match your needs.  Most perks can be provided in person in the Chicagoland area, or via phone, or Skype.  Please contact us at info@the-care-plan.com to modify perks.  
Client & Community Support  "When I was diagnosed with fast growing cervical cancer, Jackie's presence with me in doctor's appointments, during surgery, and in the recovery room gave me the confidence I needed to navigate successfully through a terrifying crisis, my way. I highly recommend Ms. Boyd's advocacy and health crisis management services for anyone facing a personal health emergency. She will ensure that you are steering your own destiny, and will support your choices in each step of your recovery journey."    
                                                                                  - Penny  
                                                                                     2012 Client
"Ms. Jacqueline Boyd is by far one of the hardest working activist for the LGBTQI community I have ever had the pleasure of working with. As a former fellow Leadership Team Member of a nonprofit that we both helped create from the ground up, I have gotten the opportunity to observe Jacqueline's ability to help uplift and empower those individuals in her community who have been neglected, ignored, or have had their voices silenced. It's not possible to find a more loving and dedicated person to help you navigate a sometimes difficult healthcare system and help you find the right solutions to your family's health care needs." 
                                                                                  -Dr. Katrina Sanford                                                                                   Clinical Psychologist                                                                                   Washington, DC 
"Jackie Boyd's number one asset: she puts people first.  Jackie's passion for LGBTQI justice crosses boundaries of race, class, and geography as she brings together people who care deeply about the needs of LGBTQI persons.  As a pastor, I've experienced Jackie's commitment to help elders in the congregation navigate their care needs -- in particular, Jackie helped an older gay man (with no children, whose partner was deceased) to think about his future with his extended family and his church family; her compassion and knowledge combined to assist in moving him to the next step."
                                                                                   - Rev. Lois McCullen-Parr

story:
Short Summary

  • Nutrient dense, whole, and organic food has always been important to me. I have lived with Crohn’s disease for over 30 years, and finally had to evict a very diseased colon. I thought my dreams of continuing this farm were over for me and my husband, but to the contrary, that gave me freedom, strength, energy and stamina to build this farm and business and the will and perseverance to fight and survive.  If I can keep one person healthy by offering farm fresh products, then everything I have experienced and learned is worth it. Its personal to me. Food should be personal, everyone should know where their food comes from, who is growing it, how it is grown and what is in it.
  • We provide value to the world by having a small carbon footprint and providing nutritious food grown using organic and permaculture practices.
  • We want our contributors to share in the idea that safe, natural, chemical free products for the body and their home is the kind of forward thinking we need in the 21st century.

What We Need & What You Get

How much money do we need?

We’ve identified three key areas to focus our funding effort to expand our farm; facilities, equipment, and start-up operational expenses. The total cost of the project is $97,000 and breakout as follows:

    • Facilities:
      • To reach the true potential of our farm and acreage, we need infrastructure. Animals will be contained with almost a mile of fencing, a new barn will be erected to shelter the herd to include attached milking stations and milk processing room, and a soap studio with retail space.
      • The soap studio, milking room, and milk processing room will be a steel structure built atop a concrete slab.
      • The barn will be a wooden structure.
      • We will relocate the current chicken coop and expand the flock to 200 birds. The relocation of the coop will provide the birds with an additional 2 acres of free range space from their current one acre of space. This will increase our egg production by ten times its current rate.
      • The facilities will be built to code and the milk processing room will be incompliance with USDA guidelines. The milk room, processing room, and soap studio will have full utilities as well as a separate septic tank rated for food production runoff and waste.
    • Equipment:
      • Equipment to support operations have been identified and resides almost entirely with the goat milk operation. Equipment includes (not entire list) milk cooler, milk pumping and vacuum system, stainless steel regulation sinks, birthing equipment, storage vats, shelves, farm tools, upgraded refrigeration equipment.
      • To expand our current beehive operation of three hives, five new hives will be purchased. Additionally, honey extraction equipment will be purchased. Currently we utilized the equipment from the local bee keepers’ association.
    • Startup Operational Expenses:
      • Startup operational expenses will include the purchase of fifteen goats “in milk”, five bee “nuks” with queens, additional chickens, straw and saw dust for the chickens, feed for both goats and chickens, vet care and animal medical supplies, supplies for bees, cleaning and sterilization equipment, fuel and diesel, initial utility connection expenses, and office supplies.

Cost of Project

$97,000

Distribution

Facilities

$61,000

PERKS!

Our true potential will blossom by great contributors giving us the support and strength we need to build and share this dream with others. We want to do our part in honoring the contributors for believing in our farm and business. Therefore, we are offering perks starting at $20 dollars by sharing products from our farm. Here is the breakout of our perks:

Contributions

Perks

$20

Recognition on a dedicated page on our website fan page

$50

A bar of soap plus the Perk above.

$75

A T-shirt plus the first two Perks.

$100

%10 off all products on our website for a year plus the first three perks above.

$175

%20 off all products on our website for a year, a bar of soap, plus a T-shirt and recognition.

$250

A fruit tree for the bees planted in your name plus the "$175 perk"

$500

Two fruit trees for the bees planted in your name plus %25 off all products on our website for a year, plus, a bar of soap, T-shirt, and  recognition.

$1,000

Get to name a goat, two t-shirts, 5 bars of soap, two fruit tree for the bees in your name, plus 35% off all products on our website for a year and recognition.

$5,000

Name a goats, 10 bars of soap, two T-shirts, two fruit trees for the bees in your name, Plus %40 off all products on our website for a year and recognition.

$10,000

A two night stay at a local bed and breakfast (Travel not included), a personal tour of the wineries on the Natchez Trace wine trail, meet the goats on our farm, name a goat, %50 off all products on our website for a year, three t-shirts, plus recognition



If we fall short of our funding goal:

  • We chose flexible funding because we know that we can put value and interest into any dollar received. Falling short is a risk that we’ve identified in pursuing this crowd funding effort. A risk that can only be mitigated by descaling the original idea, pursuing alternate funding such as loans or to quite the project in its entirety. Quitting is not an option for us so we will continue with what we gratefully receive and either descale the scope of our vision, pursue a farm loan or both.
  • Our project is designed for scalability by prioritizing expansion areas in the market arena we are pursuing; goats milk. The goat operation is the primary effort since we are already established with egg production, honey, and hand crafted soaps.
    • If our campaign fails to reach it goals, the size and scope of the goat operation to include the facilities will be adjusted to what we can afford. The chicken, honey, and soap operations will remain in its current state.
    • Our focus will be building the barn, the milking room, and the milk processing room despite the shortage. The market demand for goat milk is growing and we will remain steadfast in entering this market arena.

If we exceed our funding goal:

We have 20 acres of land and a million acres of ideas. All funding in excess of our goal will stay within the business of expanding our farm. There are several properties within our vicinity that we would purchase and expand the goat operation. The bee hive operations would grow as well as the chicken egg production. Exceeding our goal could leverage us to a position to actually provide jobs for our community sooner than planned as the funds would be full accounted for as we continue to invest in growth.



The Impact

  • We are valuable to the world by having a small carbon footprint and providing nutritious food grown using organic and permaculture practices. Contributors share in the vision that safe, natural, chemical free products for the body and their home is the kind of forward thinking we need in the 21st century.
  • Stephanie has been self-employed for over twenty years in addition to building two businesses that creates bath and body care products. Moving to the farm in 2008 provided ample opportunity to exercise our experience in handcrafted bath and body care. Since moving here, we have discussed developing these 20 acres into a working farm with goats and chickens and eventually attaining the ability to provide jobs for people in the community. We have planned for years and have white boards full of ideas and strategies, but lack the kind of funding we need to move this dream to the next level.

Risks & Challenges

We acknowledge that every venture has risk and have developed a risk management strategy to avoid or mitigate those risk. It’s also important to note that some risk can exploit opportunity and likewise, those too are tracked and assessed. We started by first evaluating our own strengths and weaknesses, personally and as a business farm, then market opportunities and threats. We table topped likely scenarios in each function to operate our farm and identified potential risk in three key areas; operational, business, and market.


Potential risks are first qualified by identifying “uncertainties” rather than “issues then annotated in our risk register. These risk are then analyzed for their likelihood of occurrence and consequential impact based on its effect on either cost, schedule, or performance (quality). By doing so, the consequence of the risk occurring in cost or time (or both) can then be calculated. We then determine the potential “trigger”, or conditions that create the risk and prepare a mitigation plan. The mitigation plan will identify short and long-term actions that will be taken to reduce or eliminate the risk or escalate the opportunity. Mitigation sometimes come at a cost or schedule slip so we compare the cost of risk against implementing mitigation actions to determine whether we will avoid, eliminate, accept, or divert those risks.

Stephanie has a very unique skillset that combined with Chuck’s education and experience, provides a holistic approach to the way we run our business and our plans for goats in the future. Stephanie is a Reiki Master, Holistic Health Coach and Practitioner, Registered Aromatherapist and Licensed Esthetician. She has worked in the holistic health care field and specializes in Therapeutic Aromatherapy, Flower Essence Therapy, Holistic Nutrition, Guided Meditation, and Reiki for over twenty years. These qualifications and unique understanding of therapeutic grade essentials oils has developed a recognized brand in our soap and other body care products.

After Chuck left the military, he was a program and project manager for a major company before deciding to leave the rat race. He has a proven resume managing projects in the hundreds of millions of dollars specializing in building and managing projects using PMP methods and specializing in risk management and earned value management. He has served the community for 24 years in the military and now want to serve my community as a farmer providing fresh organic home grown milk, eggs, and honey.

Chuck has studied business and science; He holds a Master’s of Science degree in Project Management and a Master’s of Science degree in Aerospace. Sure those degrees mean nothing when your scooping a coop, birthing a goat, or untangling horns from a fence. I can assure my contributors that the 24 years I served in the military has prepared me for the early mornings, hard work, late nights, and reactive crisis action planning that goes on daily in a farmer’s life. Also, we have been on our farm since 2008 tending to the acreage, bees, and chickens.  Chuck’s education and experience in project management will serve to run the business, financials, logistics, and marketing while the science part of him will serve to qualify and quantify trends, define and track metrics and all the cool math that goes with it, and ultimately, care for the animals.

We will solve these challenges with due diligence. We are meticulous is business, keeping documentation and operating on facts and unobjectionable and empirical data. We are extremely conscientious to our animals and take pride in our environment and the credence we hold to our customer. Money never takes precedence over the health and welfare of our animals nor the integrity of our products.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word to your to your friends and family, facebook friends, Instagram, Twitter, and other social outlets. The possibilities here are endless.

story:
This campaign is for a fellow soldier.

During Operation Iraqi Freedom 2003-2004 (OIF1) , the soldiers of the 744th MP BN were called to active duty and deployed to Iraq. We made our way up the Main Supply Route and set up HQ at Tallil Airbase. We had no running water, no electricity and we made our home in an old bombed out building.
Our only respite from the daily grind and up-tempo of our mission was a small nook at the end of the hall of that old wreck of a building. There, one of our soldiers, Letty Caban, took it upon herself to make coffee for her fellow soldiers. Every morning she brewed one pot after the other, never asking for anything in return. Every morning the troops would gather and share stories, jokes, laughs and even a few tears now and again.
As word of Caban's great coffee started spreading throughout the airbase, service members from all around would stop by and share in this makeshift oasis. An oasis they dubbed Café Cabana. They would bring tributes of every kind, from coffee, to creamers to sugar and filters. People would leave their cups and chairs there to come back to when they had some down time. Coffee time was much more than coffee and not just in the morning. Café Cabana became a social gathering amongst comrades. A boost for morale and the welfare of our troops. Some would bring their guitars and start a jam session. Others would sing along while others would just sit and forget for the moment where they were. One bold combat engineer, brought a bulldozer, leveled off the sand and built a deck so that those in attendance could gather. Every morning as the sun rose over the horizon and every evening as it gave way to the multitude of stars that illuminated the night sky, Café  Cabana was the place to be.
The dream to bring Cafe Cabana back to serve our veterans and local community is about to become a reality. But we need your help. Help Letty raise $35,000 to get Cafe Cabana up and running.

story:
Our Story


Empowering artisans. Protecting the environment. Supporting dreams.

Inti Totes is a social enterprise that sells reusable tote bags crafted by artisans in Peru. We offer a plastic-free shopping kit comprised of an “Inti Tote”, one reusable mesh produce bag and one reusable bulk bag. Our tote bags help reduce the plastic consumption by offering alternatives to the commonly used plastic grocery and produce bags. Inti Totes provides a fair paying job to a Peruvian artisan. In addition, we give back part of our profits to support education in the artisans’ community. 

Inti Totes offers customers the opportunity to make a triple impact on this world: 

1) reduce plastic consumption by using a plastic-free shopping kit 

2) empower Peruvian artisans by paying them fair wages

3) investing back in underserved communities by supporting education

Inti Tote strives be a socially conscious company and is committed to fostering entrepreneurship in impoverished communities in Peru.

In order to cover the start up cost for this venture we have decided to make this Indiegogo page. Its completely understandable if you are unable to donate at the moment but it will still help us immensely if you could share our page with your friends and family. 


The Inti Totes Family
My name is Gabriella Cepeda and I am a high school Junior at Palmer Trinity School. I was born in Miami but both my parents are Peruvian. I have always felt the need to give back to the country that gave me so much culture. As a result I have set out on this venture. 
I have since recruited my two older sisters. Their professional backgrounds and my eagerness to make a difference has allowed us to  form a strong, dynamic team that is ready to embark on this new adventure. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

     Mi nombre es Gabriela Cepeda y estoy en el onceavo grado de secundaria en el colegio Palmer Trinity School en Miami, Florida. Yo nací en Miami, pero mis padres son Peruanos y siempre he sentido la necesidad de devolver al país que me dio tanta cultura. Mi plan para hacer esto es iniciar una empresa que tendrá un impacto al medio ambiente en mi comunidad local, desarrollar a los artesanos de Perú y apoyar education en la comunidad del artesano.  

Esta empresa se llama Inti Totes. Inti Totes  son bolsas de tela con diseños incaico, hechas por un artesano peruano e importados  aquí para la venta al publico. El producto esta hecho de materiales naturales, no emplea nada de plástico. Un kit es compuesto de un Inti Tote, 1 bolsas de tela para los vegetales y 1 bolsa para los productos vendido al granel. El objetivo de la venta de estas bolsas de mercado reusables  es reducir el uso de bolsas de plástico en Miami y cambiar un habito informando a la población como iluso de plástico afecta a la comunidad local y al mundo. parte de las utilidades sera destinado para apoyar education en la comunidad del artesano en Peru.  

Para poder cubrir el costo inicial de esta empresa he decidido hacer la pagina Indiegogo para tratar de recaudar la mayor parte del dinero necesario. 

Es completamente comprensible si no puede donar en este momento pero también nos ayudaría enormemente si pudiera compartir nuestra pagina con sus amigos y familiares.
story_txt:
Our Story
Empowering artisans. Protecting the environment. Supporting dreams.
Inti Totes is a social enterprise that sells reusable tote bags crafted by artisans in Peru. We offer a plastic-free shopping kit comprised of an “Inti Tote”, one reusable mesh produce bag and one reusable bulk bag. Our tote bags help reduce the plastic consumption by offering alternatives to the commonly used plastic grocery and produce bags. Inti Totes provides a fair paying job to a Peruvian artisan. In addition, we give back part of our profits to support education in the artisans’ community. 
Inti Totes offers customers the opportunity to make a triple impact on this world: 
1) reduce plastic consumption by using a plastic-free shopping kit 
2) empower Peruvian artisans by paying them fair wages
3) investing back in underserved communities by supporting education
Inti Tote strives be a socially conscious company and is committed to fostering entrepreneurship in impoverished communities in Peru.
In order to cover the start up cost for this venture we have decided to make this Indiegogo page. Its completely understandable if you are unable to donate at the moment but it will still help us immensely if you could share our page with your friends and family. 

The Inti Totes Family

I have since recruited my two older sisters. Their professional backgrounds and my eagerness to make a difference has allowed us to  form a strong, dynamic team that is ready to embark on this new adventure. 
_____________________________________________________________________________

story:
Zia Comida & Zia Energia- A partnership for New Mexico

Hello, we are Zia Comida.. New Mexico's premier Local & Organic Foodtruck!!  We have partnered with Zia Energia drink company to offer quality sustainable food and beverage products that benefit the local community.

What We Need & What You Get

To help us achieve our objective, here is an idea of what we are looking to accomplish:

  • We are asking for $50,000 to assist in completing and launching the foodtruck and energy drink product line.  Proceeds will also go towards hosting youth & community events locally around the state.
  • We offer a myriad of Amazing and Unique prizes for our sponsors including custom art pieces & clothing, mural & graphic design work, event hosting, and special product discount rewards for our partners!!
  • Funds go towards operation and startup costs for the foodtruck and garden facility from which Zia Comida sources its ingredients. Along with assisting in the launch of the highly anticipated Zia Energia ENERGY drinks!!
  • Included in the total of our goal would cover the cost of the building of mobile skate ramps and rails that could be transported to communities that lack a skatepark and activate areas of a neighborhood in need of inspiration!

The Impact

With your contribution, you will be helping launch a completely Local and community driven campaign which seeks to restructure the "business as usual" model by providing an alternative that is sustainable and dedicated to the benefit of Local communities.

  • Zia Energia is a B-corporation which dedicates 100% of profits towards the Zia Pueblo along with other surrounding Indigenous tribes and New Mexico community projects.
  • Zia Comida hosts and organizes youth-based arts and fitness community events throughout New Mexico. 
  • Food & beverage products are made using Locally sourced ingredients which utilize organic and all natural processes from farm to table. 
  •  Zia Comida purchases  from Local farms when unable to obtain produce from its own family operated garden facility. 
  • Both companies are Locally owned and operated out of the state of New Mexico.

Risks & Challenges

On the path to reach our goals are always obstacles and hurdles we must overcome.  Some of the difficulties we face as an enterprise seeking to operate with an alternative business model is funding to keep the Movement going.  With both companies still in their developmental stages, finding the resources to gain momentum has been challenging but not deterring to the spirit of the satisfaction knowing the benefits of reaching our goals. 

  • Zia Energia has prior experience and connection in beverage marketing and distribution for other drink products both locally and internationally.
  • By aligning with already present networks and infrastructure for both bottling and distribution, Zia Energia can keep production costs low while still empowering Local businesses and communities.
  • Zia Comida has already established itself within the youth community by hosting events and creating a demand.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us gain momentum and spread the word amongst the people!!
  • SHARE links and "LIKE/ FOLLOW" ALL of our pages for updates and news!!!

Thank you for your SUPPORT in our efforts!!!

story:
Imagine waking up one day feeling extremely ill.  You know something is not completely right, and you have felt a noticeable lump on your breast for several months that seems to be getting larger with each passing day.  Desperation and worry overcome you like a tsunami, but you continue to keep quiet, as the potential shame of breast cancer is too great.  If you were sick from this disease, people would label you a pariah and you would embarrass your whole family.  However, the thought of your duty to your children and family takes priority.  "What will my family do without me here to take care of them and love them?  How will my children make it in such a harsh world without my teachings and wisdom?"  Overcome by emotion, you decide to seek medical help.  However, you quickly realize that there is nowhere to go for quality healthcare.  Finally, you locate a non-profit organization that provides free mammograms.  As you anticipate the worst, several thoughts come to mind, such as the cost of treatment. “I can either feed my family for years to come or beg and plea for money for treatment as there is no such thing as insurance or other programs to assist in healthcare.”  Finally, the results come in and you learn you have advanced stage breast cancer.  Once you learn of the treatment choices, you realize that getting better is just not feasible and you prepare to die. 

  Most women in America and other Western countries cannot imagine such a bleak outlook on breast cancer detection and treatment.  However, the women in Nigeria, Ghana and Cameroon do not have to imagine this scenario, as in most cases this is the harsh reality. Breast cancer is taboo in these countries, largely due to lack of education, and it is not an acceptable topic of discussion.  If and when a woman in one of these countries is brave enough to seek help, there is often none to be given.  Many times simple mammograms are nearly impossible to get due to the scarcity of equipment and funding, unless one is fortunate enough to locate a Western non-profit organization that provides them.  If a woman is lucky enough to have her treatment funded through a non-profit, radiation and chemotherapy regimens often take place in a room that is no more pleasant than a gas station bathroom.  Additionally, detection of the disease in these countries is typically in the latter stages, so death is the standard result.  In fact, there is a mortality rate in excess of 90% in these countries for women who have breast cancer – a stark contrast to women in the U.S. and Europe, where there is a 90% survival rate for breast cancer patients with early detection. 

  Run For A Cure Africa (RFCA) is a non-profit organization that focuses on the education and treatment of breast cancer in Nigeria, Cameroon and Ghana.  RFCA is a 501(c)(3) organization that is headquartered in Houston, Texas.  Through its efforts, RFCA has raised funds to provide mammograms for thousands of African women and treatment for hundreds.  Select areas of specialization include:

1)  Raising monies for educational materials to increase awareness regarding early prevention and treatment, as well as to remove social stigma;

2)  Bringing attention to the fact that this worldwide issue is much more severe and pronounced in the countries of Nigeria, Cameroon and Ghana;

3)  Collecting equipment and supply donations such as mammogram machines to provide free and accurate diagnoses to the patients; and

4)  Fundraising to pay for competent doctors and surgeons to travel to these countries to not only treat women with breast cancer, but also to conduct teaching forums for local medical staff.

RFCA hosts several fundraising events and challenges each year.  One of their most successful is “31 for 31”, which is a challenge for participants to run, jog, hike, bike, swim or move 31 kilometers within the 31 days of October to raise breast cancer awareness in these African countries.  Monetary donations are also greatly appreciated and can be made directly to this Indiegogo page.  Finally, equipment and supply donations are also very important, and we ask that anyone interested in donating equipment call Run For A Cure Africa directly at 01 453 6711, 0802 287 6660 or email at info@rfcafrica.org.  Last year 2,000 women were given free mammograms from the funds raised from events sponsored by RFCA.  Our goal for this particular challenge is $5,000 or more, which will provide mammograms for 50 + women. 

Will you do your part in helping us change what it means to be diagnosed with breast cancer in Africa?  We can defeat this disease together, one step at a time. 

Thank you.

"Small Steps, Big Difference!"

story:
Introduction

We are Jameliah Katherine Adekunle (also known as Jammy) and Catharine Charlotte Wippell (also known as Wippy) and we are 15 years old.

“Ever since I was 2 years old, I have had a passion for the arts. Singing, dancing, musical theatre you name it! This was developed through going to classes at a stage school near my house. I started off by going once a week and increased to every other day, as I got older and more interested in theatre. I was also very interested in art and fashion design from a very young age. This was probably due to the artistic talent that runs through my family. My mother enjoyed art as a child and my auntie and uncle are now both successful architects. However, I think it has mostly to do with my cousin Tommy drawing various things for me and I copying them. I had numerous amounts of books on drawing including the most pointless things like how to draw mermaids or dragons.” – Jameliah Adekunle (Producer and Director of J.C.C.A)

The Impact

Jammy’s Children’s Company for the Arts’ (J.C.C.A) mission is to get young people to have the talent and flare to develop a career in the any of the arts industries, whether that is as a world-renowned musician, the next Jimmy Choo or Darcey Bussell. We aim to produce a variety of events that will give them that extra push that they need in these competitive industries.

“I have always wanted to go into one of the arts industries and believe that I will get there through persevering and practicing. I believe that J.C.C.A will help me just as much it will help the other children! Being able to excel in the arts industry requires a lot of confidence and strength and I hope J.C.C.A can provide this.” – Jameliah Adekunle (Producer and Director of J.C.C.A)

Risks & Challenges

We have realised that there are many obstacles that we may face in creating J.C.C.A such as the great cost in which putting on these events includes. The hair, the makeup, the costumes and the theatre all-subtotal to a huge amount of money. Another obstacle would be the time and effort that goes into putting on these types of events. However, we believe that we can solve these challenges through help from campaigns and from other people with the same amount of passion as we have.

What We Need & What You Get

Our first production will be going ahead in 2016 as the production of the hit Broadway musical, the Lion King. This is a world renowned musical and has a lot of scope to be incredible. However, it will be a huge challenge as there are many obstacles that we may face. This is why we need your help. So far, we have worked out that the cost for hiring the theatre for the technical and dress rehearsal as well as the two evening performances will be  roughly £6,000. As you can imagine, this is a lot of money for two teenage girls! We also would have to hire out dance and drama studios for the rehearsals to take place, the making of the costumes, set and for special effects as well as extra costs for advertising i.e flyers, posters etc. We are striving to gain at least £6,000 for this project and this is not the only way we are going to get there. We are trying to get sponsorship funds from other companies that are interested in developing the arts sector in young people.

Budget Plan Lion King J.C.C.A Venue Hire Rates Half Day (4 hours) Full Day (8 hours)
Crowdfunding Target: £6,000 C1- Performance(s)-x2 C1- Technical and Dress Rehearsal       C1 £600 £1,100
Venue Hire (C1 includes 2 dressing rooms, green room, projector and screen) £2,200.00 £2,200.00       C3 £200 £400
Technical Staff £176.00 £176.00     Extras: Technical Staff £176
Event Lead £120.00 £120.00       Event Lead   £60
Ushers £264.00 n/a       Usher   £132
Total: £2,760.00 £2,496.00       VAT   20%
VAT: £552.00 £499.20            
Sub-Total: £3,312.00 £2,995.20            
  £6,307.20            
               
C3- Rehearsals              
Total: £3,200.00            
VAT: £640.00            
Sub-Total: £3,840.00            
               
               
Overall Cost: £10,147.20            
               



Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. You can help by just spreading the word about this project and J.C.C.A in general. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools. We really need all the help that we can get! 

If you or you know anyone between the age of 9 and 16 who would be interested in auditioning for Lion King in the Summer of 2016 then please ask them to contact Jammy on 07772463064 or by email: jammyka@hotmail.com
